U. S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, EDUCATION. AND WELFARE

' PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION

Rockvillo Maryland 2085 2

NEWS Edward J. Chapin: 301 496-7623
Home Phone: 703 437-1789

71-58

FOR IMIEDIATYE RELEASE
SEPTEMBER 27, 1971

Liniments and other liquid preparations containing more than
5 percent of methyl salicylate (Wintergreen oil) would be required to be
marketed in special child-resistant containers with restricted openings
under regulations being proposed by the Food and Drug Administration

Charles C. Edwards, M.D., Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said
injury reports to FDA's Bureau of Product Safety and other government agencies
show that 176 accidental ingestions of methyl salicylate by children under
five years of age occurred in a 3-year period, 1968 through 1970. Of these,

33 children were hospitalized and eight died.

. "This product is attractive to children because of its winter-
green odor," Dr. Edwards said. "As little as one teaspoon of methyl salicylate
has been reported to be fatal."

Dr. Edwards pointed out that this action is the third proposedv
standard by FDA under authority of the Poison Prevention Packaging Act requiring
special packaging for dangerous substances found in the household. Recently pro-
mulgated standards include special packaging for aspirin preparations and
furniture oil containing 10 percent or more of petroleum distillates.

The special packaging would be designed so that not more than 2
mﬂliliters (less than half a teaspoon) will flow from the container when it is
inverted and shaken or squeezed once. Also, the standard would require that 85

percent of a test group of,200 children (ages 41 to 52 months) be unable to

-MORE-


 

-2-

open the container and that 80 percent fail after a demonstration of how to
open it. Ninety percent of a test group of 100 adults must be able to open
and close the container.

The proposed regulations, which have been reviewed by the
Poison Prevention Packaging Act technical advisory committee, will be published
in the September 29,,197l issue of the FEDERAL REGISTER. Interested persons
may, within 30 days, file comments with the Hearing Clerk, Room 6-88,

5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, Maryland 20852.

# # #

71-59 . Home: 301-460-9663
FOR RELEASE IN A.M. PAPERS

FRIDAY - OCTOBER 8, 1971

The Food and Drug Administration proposed today to require that .

equipment manufactured for x ray diagnosis in the healing arts incorporate

new radiation controi 1eatures to reduce patient and operator exposure
during x-ray examinations.

The action was taken by pubiication in the Federai Reaister of a
proposed performance standard covering both medical and dentai diagnostic
x-ray equipment: The standard was deveioped by the FDA Bureau of Radio-
Iogicai Heaith under the Radiation Centre? for Health and Safety Act.

' X-ray examinations, the FDA noted, constitute the iargest singie
source of man-made radiation reaching the American peopie.

,"whiie the beneficiaT appiications of x radiation in the heaiing
arts are weil recognized, exposures_frem diagnostic x—ray procedures‘
have far more pubiic heaith significance than exposures from aii other
man-made radiation sources,” said Charies C. Edwards, M.D., Food and
Drug Commissioner. “More than 90 percent of a1? human exposure to man-
made radiation comes from the diagnostic use of X ray in contrast with
about one percent from radioactiVe discharges from nuclear power piants

about which there has been so much pubiic concern.“

(more)


 

- 2 -

I _Twogprovisions_of the standard are regarded as representing.out—
standing progress in diagnostic x-ray exposure control. One would require
stationary general purpose x-ray machines to be designed to insure
limitation of the beam to approximately the size of the body area to be
examined. The other would require radiographic (film using) equipment to
be able consistently to reproduce exposure and, therefore, image quality
for given settings for voltage, current, and time.

Failure to keep the xeray beam within the area of the body undergoing
diagnostic examination is one of the commonest causes of unnecessary x-ray
exposure; Bureau of Radiological Health studies show, for example, that
a reduction of as much as 50 percent or more in the genetically significant
dose from diagnostic x ray can result from limiting the beam to approximately
the size of the film or other x-ray receptor. The genetically significant
dose is the dose that may be harmful to future generations.

The exposure reproducibility requirement of the standard would enable
the technologist to know with greater confidence than is now possible what
results to expect.at various-equipment¥settings-and thus to avoid picture
retakes, also a common cause of unnecessary diagnostic x-ray exposure.

Beam limitation in stationary general purpose equipment would have ‘
to be insured, under the proposed standard, either by the incorporation of
devices for automatically adjusting the beam to film or receptor size or
by the use of interlocking systems that would prevent x rays from being
produced until the eQuipment has been manually adjusted to restrict the
beam. Other types of diagnostic x-ray equipment also would have to

standing progress in diagnostic x-ray exposure control. One would require

examined. The other wouid require radiographic (fiTm using) equipment to
be abie consistently to reproduce exposure and, therefore, image quaTity
for giyen settings for voTtage, current, and time. V

Faiiure to keep the xeray beam within the area of the body undergoing
diagnostic examination is one of the commonest causes of unnecessary x-ray
exposure. Bureau of RadioTOQicaT HeaTth studies show. for exampie, that
a reduction of as much as 50 percent or more in the geneticaiiy significant
dose from diagnostic x ray can resuit from iimiting the beam to approximately
the size of the fiim or other x-ray receptor. The geneticaiiy significant
dose is the dose that may be harmfui to future generations.

The exposure reproducibiiity requirement of the standard would enabie
the technoiogist to know with greater confidence than is now possibie what
results to expect.at various equipment settings and thus-to avoid picture
retakes, also a common cause of unnecessary diagnostic x—ray exposure.

Beam Timitation in stationary generai purpose equipment woqu have
to be insured, under the proposed standard, either by the incorporation of
devices for automaticaTTy adjusting the beam to fiim or receptor size or
by the use of interiocking systems that wouid prevent x rays from being

,produced untii the equipment has been manuaiiy adjusted to restrict the
beam. Other types of diagnostic x-ray equipment aTso wouid have to

>(more)


-3-

provide for beam restriction, but means other than automatic or interlocked
restriction could be used.

The proposed standard also would limit the amount of leakage from
x-ray sources in diagnostic equipment. This would be TOO milliroentgens
in one hour measured at one meter in any direction from the source. The
proposed limitation, the FDA said, is "in substantial accord" with
recommendations of the National Council on Radiation Protection and
Measurements and the International Commission on Radiological Protection.

The FDA added that the proposed radiation leakage limit is considered
to be appropriate “in view of the small exposures from leakage radiation
relative to other sources of x radiation to which the patient is exposed
during a diagnostic examination.”

The leakage limitation would apply to the x-ray tube within its

housing and with a beam-limiting device in place, rather than in terms

of a single component, such as the tube. Manufacturers of beam-limiting

devices would be required to specify tube housing assemblies with which
their products would be compatible in terms of leakage limitation
compliance.

X4ray equipment manufacturers would be given a year following the
effective date of the standard to produce equipment complying with its
provisions. The proposed standard would become effective upon republication

in the Federal Reoister after 60 days for public comment.
